item.title: Book Cover: Barnabas Horton
item.dc:creator: Brent Lagerman
item.description:
We're really excited to share with you our first book cover design! Barnabas Horton - The Yeoman of Long Island will be published later this year. It tells the story of one of Long Island's early settlers, who despite the legend was an ordinary man.

The post Book Cover: Barnabas Horton appeared first on mimoYmima.
item.content:encoded:
We’re really excited to share with you our first book cover design! Barnabas Horton – The Yeoman of Long Island will be published later this year. It tells the story of one of Long Island’s early settlers, who despite the legend was an ordinary man. We are working on a website for the book at the moment, it will be available for pre-order soon!

barnabashorton.com

The post Book Cover: Barnabas Horton appeared first on mimoYmima.

item.title: Eye Shoppe on Seventh
item.dc:creator: Brent Lagerman
item.description:
We're creating the identity for Eye Shoppe on Seventh. Some directions we're exploring include French script, clean/modern, and quirky/bold. It's a work in progress, so check back here for more updates soon.

The post Eye Shoppe on Seventh appeared first on mimoYmima.
item.content:encoded:
The Eye Shoppe has been on Seventh Ave in Park Slope since 1991, we wanted to show a little bit of that history in the website design, so we borrowed inspiration from their beautiful tin ceiling.

What a fantastic group…..they designed our business website and logo and I couldn’t be happier. They worked with me personally to get it right, and it came out great! From the initial idea to inception they were a call away, and even helped me with marketing ideas! I totally recommend them! Thanks guys!

â€“ Richie Livan


The images below show the process we went through to develop their new identity and logo.

Chosen Color Scheme

Color

Concepts

Here’s a few of the other directions we explored: French script, clean modern, and quirky/bold.

The post Eye Shoppe on Seventh appeared first on mimoYmima.

item.title: Beygl
item.dc:creator: Brent Lagerman
item.description:
This new Park Slope eatery has amazing bagels, or as they like to call them, beygls. They are true to the old school methods, creating them in small batches with the best ingredients.

The post Beygl appeared first on mimoYmima.
item.content:encoded:
This new Park Slope eatery has *amazing* bagels, or as they like to spell them: beygls. The funny spelling comes from the word’s yiddish origin. These guys really know and love the process of making these things, so we spent some time illustrating a cool process page that shows how it’s done. We also like how they source wholesome local ingredients from other New York and Brooklyn vendors. You can check out their delicious menu on the website, or if you’re in the Slope stop by and pick up a beygl.

Illustration and Design

* visit the site

The post Beygl appeared first on mimoYmima.

item.title: In Progress: Park Slope Civic Council
item.dc:creator: Brent Lagerman
item.description:
For the last few months we have been working on the redesign of the site for the Park Slope Civic Council, a non-profit organization that is an incredible resource to our community.

The post In Progress: Park Slope Civic Council appeared first on mimoYmima.
item.content:encoded:
For the last few months we have been working on the redesign of the site for the Park Slope Civic Council, a non-profit organization that holds this part of Brooklyn together and is an incredible resource to our community.

We worked closely with David Herman Studio on the site, coming up with the right look and feel, and customizing the content management system.

The post In Progress: Park Slope Civic Council appeared first on mimoYmima.

item.title: AlterBrook Renovations
item.dc:creator: Brent Lagerman
item.description:
AlterBrook was started by Daniel Alter, an architect living in Park Slope, Brooklyn. He expanded his business to include renovation of hand picked townhouses and needed a way to publicize the properties and find buyers.

The post AlterBrook Renovations appeared first on mimoYmima.
item.content:encoded:
AlterBrook was started by Daniel Alter, an architect living in Park Slope, Brooklyn. He expanded his business to include renovation of hand picked townhouses and needed a way to publicize the properties and find buyers.

We created a site for his latest renovation which will also be used as a template for future listings as he renovates other properties.

Also check out the site we created for Daniel’s Architecture work.

The post AlterBrook Renovations appeared first on mimoYmima.

item.title: Your Website & Facebook
item.dc:creator: Brent Lagerman
item.description:
Last night mimo (AKA Brent) spoke at the Park Slope Civic Council's 'Growing a Brooklyn Business' initiative at the Montauk Club in Park Slope. Here's the notes we put together for the event and some thoughts that came afterward.

The post Your Website & Facebook appeared first on mimoYmima.
item.content:encoded:
Last night mimo (AKA Brent) spoke at the Park Slope Civic Council’s ‘Growing a Business’ initiative at the Montauk Club in Park Slope. Here’s the notes we put together for the event and some thoughts that came afterward.

Your Website

Matt Mullenweg (The creator of WordPress) had this to say about publishing your own content on a website or blog vs using Facebook and Twitter:

Blogging (with WordPress) is the natural evolution of the lighter publishing methods â€” at some point youâ€™ll have more to say than fits in 140 characters, is too important to put in Facebookâ€™s generic chrome, or youâ€™ve matured to the point where you want more flexibility and control around your words and ideas… Different mediums offer different messages.

The most important part of the quote above (to us) is: (your message) is too important to put in Facebookâ€™s generic chrome … A good and experienced Web Developement Company is really important as for Having a website/blog lets you brand your ideas in a way that you can’t on social media sites, if you don’t spend time/money on that brand, your image is less likely to be taken seriously and you also want to attract the right customer by having a appealing web design look, and a good SEO or search engine optimization which will help the market expand their visibility so you can be find by more possible customers and reach out to more.

With WordPress you can have a powerful website builder, which has evolved throughout the years to a robust content management system to power their websites. WordPress has become (by far) the most popular Content Management System for making websites. It’s literally a joy for web developers to make templates for this system, you can have any look imaginable, and it’s not a pain to implement it. Of course it is always better to find a proper professional website developers which helps you improve and make a new market for your service or business.

How important is Facebook?

We’ve been integrating Facebook ‘like’ buttons and links to Facebook & Twitter pages into all designs for a while now. According to the Jacksonville SEO company, facebook has become a part of nearly every business’ marketing strategy and it’s for good reason. Google Trends, a service that shows search volume worldwide, shows that the activity for facebook is MUCH higher than Twitter. The top part of this graph shows the search activity of both:

Business teams and small businesses should make their employees admins on their facebook account so they don’t need to do all the work themselves â€” instructions for making someone a facebook admin.

I’m not trying to say that you shouldn’t be using Twitter, just that you absolutely need to be using Facebook. Twitter has it’s place and connects you to different people.

Change Your Workflow

You need to find a way to effortlessly integrate social media into your everyday routine.

You have a blog, you have a Facebook account, you have a Twitter account… there’s not really much of a point to have all these things if they’re just going to accumulate digital dust… sometimes you do need professional help, and this is one of those cases, so make sure to check the digital agency listings if you want to save your online business.

A few suggestions:

  • If you find yourself taking notes on paper or in text documents in your computer that somehow relate to your business, change over to writing them as blog posts. The benefit of this is that they will be archived automatically so you can search for them later, you’ll also be able to drive more traffic to your site because these posts will have keywords in them that are relevant to your business. Also people might comment on them and you’ll make new connections.
  • Look at your Facebook wall EVERY DAY as part of your routine. Find ways to connect with people through your posts. If you’re not finding this easy to do, keep at it or have someone else at your business keep up with it, no excuses.
  • You should link up your Blog and your Facebook account so when you publish a blog post it automatically shows up on Facebook.

Someone had a good question last night which was hard to answer and has been sticking with me:

How do you know if you’re posting too much or being annoying to people…

It’s a legitimate concern. If you feel like what you’re writing is going to annoy people you’re probably right. It takes a certain skill to be able to talk about yourself and your business so if you don’t have it you should hire someone to do your PR person, this could even be new junior level employee you already have.

The post Your Website & Facebook appeared first on mimoYmima.

item.title: Calder’s Flat
item.dc:creator: Brent Lagerman
item.description:
Calder’s Flat is a unique guesthouse nestled into a quaint block in Park Slope, Brooklyn. The owner, Jackie Dinan, wanted a branded look and custom website designed for the guesthouse to help distinguish her business. We created a classic look that matches her style, check it out:

item.title: 2009 Snowflake Festival
item.dc:creator: Brent Lagerman
item.description:
We just made the website for Park Slope, Brooklyn's 3rd Annual Snowflake Festival.

The post 2009 Snowflake Festival appeared first on mimoYmima.
item.content:encoded:
We just made the website for Park Slope, Brooklyn’s 3rd Annual Snowflake Festival.

In their words:

Local merchants once again throw open their doors to stay open late and create a holiday atmosphere, enabling you, the people of Park Slope, to do your holiday shopping . . . here! Each participating business will 1). Stay open until 10pm, and 2). Offer some special promotion – Could be a sale, could be a giveaway, raffle, carolers, snow machine (it’s been done!), mulled wine, special hors d’oeuvres, etc.

Visit the Buy In Brooklyn site for more info and a list of participants.

Also check out the poster designed by Sarah Sills.

The post 2009 Snowflake Festival appeared first on mimoYmima.

item.title: Our new winter ad

item.content:encoded:
It’s that time again, we just designed our Park Slope Reader Quarterly ad, here’s a preview. I originally posted the first try below, but Teresa thought it looked too ‘hobo’. I was trying for cute and worn, but I agree it’s a little run down lookin… So we gave frosty a makeover and here’s what we came up with:

Second Try

First Try
